revision.text:
{{About|the literary form|other uses|Novella (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} {{Literature}} A '''novella''' is a text of written, fictional, narrative prose normally longer than a [[short story]] but shorter than a [[novel]], somewhere between 17,500 and 40,000 words. The English word "''novella''{{-"}} derives from the Italian ''novella'', feminine of ''novello'', which means "new".{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/novella |title=Novella - Definition |website=Merriam-Webster Dictionary online|accessdate= 7 March 2010}} The novella is a common [[literary genre]] in several European languages. ==History== The novella as a literary genre began developing in the early [[Renaissance]] by the Italian and French ''literatura'', principally [[Giovanni Boccaccio]], author of ''[[The Decameron]]'' (1353).{{cite web | url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/novella | title=Novella: Definition and history |website=Merriam-Webster Dictionary online| accessdate=6 February 2014}} ''The Decameron'' featured 100 tales (novellas) told by 10 people (seven women and three men) fleeing the [[Black Death]], by escaping from [[Florence]] to the Fiesole hills in 1348. This structure was then imitated by subsequent authors, notably the French queen [[Marguerite de Navarre]], whose ''[[Heptameron|Heptaméron]]'' (1559) included 72 original French tales and was modeled after the structure of ''The Decameron''. Not until the late 18th and early 19th centuries did writers fashion the novella into a literary genre structured by precepts and rules, generally in a [[Realism (arts)|realistic mode]]. At that time, the Germans were the most active writers of the ''novelle'' (German: "Novelle"; plural: "Novellen").{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} For the German writer, a novella is a fictional narrative of indeterminate length—a few pages to hundreds—restricted to a single, suspenseful event, situation, or conflict leading to an unexpected turning point (''Wendepunkt''), provoking a logical but surprising end. ''Novellen'' tend to contain a concrete symbol, which is the narrative's focal point.{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} ==Structure== A novella generally features fewer [[Conflict (narrative)|conflicts]] than a [[novel]], yet more complicated ones than a [[short story]]. The conflicts also have more time to develop than in short stories. Novellas may or may not be divided into chapters (good examples of those with chapters are ''[[Animal Farm]]'' by [[George Orwell]] and ''[[The War of the Worlds]]'' by [[H. G. Wells]]) and are often intended to be read at a single sitting, as is the short story, although in a novella white space is often used to divide the sections, and therefore, the novella maintains a single effect.{{Cite book|last=Kercheval|first=Jesse Lee|title=Building Fiction|publisher=Story Press|location=Cincinnati, Ohio|year=1997|chapter=Short shorts, novellas, novel-in-stories|isbn=1-884910-28-9}} [[Warren Cariou]] wrote:
The novella is generally not as formally experimental as the long story and the novel can be, and it usually lacks the subplots, the multiple points of view, and the generic adaptability that are common in the novel. It is most often concerned with personal and emotional development rather than with the larger social sphere. The novella generally retains something of the unity of impression that is a hallmark of the short story, but it also contains more highly developed characterization and more luxuriant description.''Encyclopedia of literature in Canada''. Edited by William H. New. University of Toronto, 2000. Page 835.
==Versus novel== :''See the article [[Novel]] for the historical generic debate''. :''See the article [[Word count]] for comparative word counts''. This etymological distinction avoids confusion of the literatures and the forms, with the novel being the more important, established fictional form.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} Austrian writer [[Stefan Zweig]]'s ''[[The Royal Game|Die Schachnovelle]]'' (1942) (literally, "The Chess Novella", but translated in 1944 as ''The Royal Game'') is an example of a title naming its genre. Commonly, longer novellas are referred to as novels; Robert Louis Stevenson's ''[[Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde]]'' (1886) and Joseph Conrad's ''[[Heart of Darkness]]'' (1899) are sometimes called novels,{{by whom|date=September 2014}} as are many [[science fiction]] works such as H. G. Wells' ''The War of the Worlds'' (1897) and Philip Francis Nowlan's ''[[Armageddon 2419 A.D.]]'' (1928). Less often, longer works are referred to as novellas. The subjectivity of the parameters of the novella genre is indicative of its shifting and diverse nature as an art form.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} In her 2010 ''[[Open Letters Monthly]]'' series, "A Year With Short Novels", Ingrid Norton criticizes the tendency to make clear demarcations based purely on a book's length:
On a web search engine, input "novels" and "length" and you will find tables of word counts, separating out novels from novellas, even from the esoteric and still shorter "novelette"—as though prose works were dog show contestants, needing to be entered into proper categories. But when it comes to writing, any distinctions that begin with an objective and external quality like size are bound to be misleading. The delicate, gem-like jigsaw of [[Thornton Wilder]]'s ''[[The Bridge of San Luis Rey|The Bridge of San Luis Ray]]'' {{sic}} could not be more unlike the feverishly cunning philosophical monologue of [[Albert Camus]]' ''[[The Fall (Camus novel)|The Fall]]'', but both novels are about the same length."[http://www.openlettersmonthly.com/the-sweetness-of-short-novels/ The Sweetness of Short Novels]" by [http://www.openlettersmonthly.com/author/norton/ Ingrid Norton], Open Letters Monthly February 2010
[[Stephen King]], in his introduction to ''[[Different Seasons]]'', a collection of four novellas, has called the novella "an ill-defined and disreputable literary banana republic";{{cite book|last=King|first= Stephen|title=Different Seasons|publisher=Viking Adult|year=1982|isbn=978-0-670-27266-2}} King notes the difficulties of selling a novella in the commercial publishing world, since it does not fit the typical length requirements of either magazine or book publishers. Despite these problems, however, the novella's length provides unique advantages; in the introduction to a novella anthology titled ''Sailing to Byzantium'', [[Robert Silverberg]] writes: {{bquote|[The novella] is one of the richest and most rewarding of literary forms...it allows for more extended development of theme and character than does the short story, without making the elaborate structural demands of the full-length book. Thus it provides an intense, detailed exploration of its subject, providing to some degree both the concentrated focus of the short story and the broad scope of the novel.{{cite book|author=Silverberg, Robert|title=Sailing to Byzantium|location=New York|publisher= ibooks, inc.|date= 2000|isbn= 0-7861-9905-9}}}} In his essay, "Briefly, the case for the novella", Canadian author George Fetherling (who wrote the novella ''Tales of Two Cities'') said that to reduce the novella to nothing more than a short novel is like "insisting that a pony is a baby horse".{{cite news|author=Fetherling, George |url=http://www.sevenoaksmag.com/commentary/94_comm1.html |title=Briefly, the case for the novella |work=Seven Oaks Magazine |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://archive.li/20120912031610/http://www.sevenoaksmag.com/commentary/94_comm1.html |archivedate=12 September 2012 |df= }} The sometimes blurry definition between a novel and a novella can create controversy, as was the case with British writer [[Ian McEwan]]'s ''[[On Chesil Beach]]'' (2007). The author described it as a novella, but the panel for the [[Man Booker Prize]] in 2007 qualified the book as a "short novel".{{cite news|title=Ian McEwan claims the novella is better than the novel|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/booknews/9608935/Ian-McEwan-claims-the-novella-is-better-than-the-novel.html|accessdate=27 September 2015|work=The Telegraph|agency=Telegraph Media Group Limited|issue=HOME»CULTURE»BOOKS»BOOK NEWS|publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited|date= 15 Oct 2012}} Thus, this "novella" was shortlisted for an award for best original novel. A similar case is found with a much older work of fiction: ''[[The Call of the Wild]]'' (1903) by [[Jack London]]. This book, by modern standards, is short enough and straightforward enough to qualify as a novella. However, historically, it has been regarded as a novel.{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} ==Versus novelette== Dictionaries define '''''novelette''''' similarly to ''novella''; sometimes identically, [[American Heritage Dictionary]] (4th ed.): [http://education.yahoo.com/reference/dictionary/entry/novella novella (2)], [http://education.yahoo.com/reference/dictionary/entry/novelette novelette]; [[Merriam-Webster]] Online Dictionary: [http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/novelette novelette]; sometimes with a disparaging sense of being trivial or sentimental. [[Collins Dictionary]]: [http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/novella novella (2)], [http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/novelette novelette (2)]; [[Macmillan Dictionary]] (US ed.): [http://www.macmillandictionary.com/dictionary/american/novella novella], [http://www.macmillandictionary.com/dictionary/american/novelette novelette]; [[Cambridge Advanced Learner's Dictionary]] (UK ed.): [http://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/british/novella novella], [http://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/british/novella novelette]; novelette]; [[Concise Oxford English Dictionary]]: [http://oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/novella?view=uk novella], [http://oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/novelette?view=uk novelette]; [[Webster's New World Dictionary]]: [http://websters.yourdictionary.com/novella novella], [http://websters.yourdictionary.com/novelette novelette]; Some [[literary award]]s have a longer "novella" and a shorter "novelette" categories, with a distinction based on [[word count]]. A range between 7,500 and 17,500 words is common among awards. ==Notable examples== This list contains those novellas that are widely considered to be the best examples of the genre, through their appearance on multiple best-of lists. See [[list of novellas]] for other notable examples. {|class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- |+ Novellas that appear on multiple best-of lists ! scope="col" | Title ! scope="col" | Author ! scope="col" | Published ! scope="col" | Reference |- ! scope="row" |'' [[Animal Farm]]'' | {{sortname|George|Orwell}} | 1945 | |- ! scope="row" |''[[Billy Budd]]'' | {{sortname|Herman|Melville}} | 1924 | |- ! scope="row" | ''[[Breakfast at Tiffany's (novella)|Breakfast at Tiffany's]]'' | {{sortname|Truman|Capote}} | 1958 | |- ! scope="row" | {{sort|Christmas Carol|''[[A Christmas Carol]]''}} | {{sortname|Charles|Dickens}} | 1843 | |- ! scope="row" | {{sort|Clockwork Orange|''[[A Clockwork Orange (novel)|A Clockwork Orange]]''}} | {{sortname|Anthony|Burgess}} | 1962 | |- ! scope="row" | ''[[Ethan Frome]]'' | {{sortname|Edith|Wharton}} | 1911 | |- ! scope="row" | ''[[Goodbye, Columbus]]'' | {{sortname|Philip|Roth}} | 1959 | |- ! scope="row" | ''[[Heart of Darkness]]'' | {{sortname|Joseph|Conrad}} | 1899 | |- ! scope="row" | ''[[I Am Legend (novel)|I Am Legend]]'' | {{sortname|Richard|Matheson}} | 1954 | |- ! scope="row" | {{sort|Metamorphosis|''[[The Metamorphosis]]''}} | {{sortname|Franz|Kafka}} | 1915 | |- ! scope="row" | ''[[Of Mice and Men]]'' | {{sortname|John|Steinbeck}} | 1937 | |- ! scope="row" | {{sort|Old Man and the Sea|''[[The Old Man and the Sea]]''}} | {{sortname|Ernest|Hemingway}} | 1952 | |- ! scope="row" | ''[[Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde]]'' | {{sortname|Robert Louis|Stevenson}} | 1886 | |- ! scope="row" | {{sort|Stranger|''[[The Stranger (Camus novel)|The Stranger]]''}} | {{sortname|Albert|Camus}} | 1942 | |- ! scope="row" | {{sort|War of the Worlds|''[[The War of the Worlds]]''}} | {{sortname|H. G.|Wells}} | 1898 | |} ==Word counts== Some [[literary awards]] include a "best novella" award and sometimes a separate "best novelette" award, separately from "best short story" or "best novel". The distinction between these categories may be entirely by [[word count]]. {|class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Award !! Genre !! Organisation !! Minimum !! Maximum !! 18 May 2016 }} {{cite web | url = http://jthorsson.com/2012/06/18/the-worlds-best-novellas/ | title = The World’s Best Novellas | website = On Books & Writing | accessdate = 18 May 2016 | date = 18 June 2012 | first = Johann | last = Thorsson }} {{cite web | url = http://thoughtcatalog.com/gordon-haber/2015/06/20-best-novellas-ever-published-in-the-history-of-mankind/ | title = The 20 Best Novellas Ever Published In The History Of Humankind | website = Thought Catalog | accessdate = 18 May 2016 | first = Gordon | last = Haber | date = 29 June 2015 }} {{cite web | url = http://www.abebooks.com/books/features/best-novellas.shtml | title = The Best Novellas: Literature's Middle Child | website = AbeBooks | accessdate = 18 May 2016 | first = Beth | last = Carswell | year = 2012 }} {{cite news | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/12/06/these-classic-books-are-s_n_4373470.html | title = These Amazing Classic Books Are So Short You Have No Excuse Not To Read Them | newspaper = [[The Huffington Post]] | accessdate = 22 May 2016 | date = 6 December 2013 }} }} ==Further reading== * {{Cite journal |last=Fassler |first=Joe |date=April 24, 2012 |title=The [[File:Mitch-stratten-OCP-helmet.jpg|thumb|right|The 'TRI' helmet used in ''OCP'' to support the performers in walking.]] {{italic title}} '''''OCP''''' is a video project by artist and filmmaker [[Mitch Stratten]]. ''OCP'' 's production process involved an elaborate weighted kinetic set which allowed a [[puppeteer]] to synchronise the surrounding architectural space with the unpredictable movement of the three performers contained. Three months of planning, construction and testing took place in a [[North London]] warehouse preceding a [[Filmmaking|film shoot]] completed in two days. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dazeddigital.com/artsandculture/article/17990/1/behind-the-scenes-of-mitch-strattens-ocp|title=Behind the scenes of Mitch Stratten’s OCP|first=|last=Dazed|date=27 November 2013|publisher=}}</ref> An additional physical challenge was for the three separate bodies, supported by a specific helmet, to walk as a fused single entity. <ref name="Sedition interview">{{cite web|url=https://www.seditionart.com/mitch-stratten|title=Interview with Mitch Stratten / OCP|website=}}</ref> The score was composed and recorded by Mitch Stratten (also known as [[Nodern Loves You|''Nodern'']]) <ref name="nts">{{cite web|url=https://www.nts.live/shows/synth-hero-show/episodes/the-synth-hero-show-16th-november-2015|author=NTS Radio|title=The Synth Hero Show W/ MITCH STRATTEN 16th November 2015 | Listen on NTS|website=nts.live|accessdate=2018-11-05}}</ref> and mastered by [[Denis Blackham]] in the [[Isle of Skye]]. ''OCP'' was first released on the [[Sedition (website)|Sedition]] distribution platform where it is curated online. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.seditionart.com/mitch-stratten/ocp|title=OCP by Mitch Stratten|website=www.seditionart.com}}</ref> ''OCP'' has further been included amongst institutional art programmes internationally. <ref name="Faculty of Arts ASAB">{{cite web|url=http://fasab.udistrital.edu.co:8080/transparencia-fluidez-y-mediacion|author=John Ángel Rodríguez, Curator, Museum of Contemporary Art Bogota, Colombia|title=Transparency, Fluidity and Mediation|website=Faculty of Arts ASAB}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/columbus/article/BWW-Review-Films-Capture-Mastery-of-Movement-in-Ohio-State-Department-of-Dances-DANCE30FPS-20160215imdb|title=BWW Review: Films Capture Mastery of Movement in Ohio State Department of Dance's DANCE@30FPS|first=Amanda|last=Etchison|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="eyefilm">{{cite web|url=https://www.eyefilm.nl/en/film/cinedans-dagpas|author=Performative Film at the EYE|title=EYE filmmuseum|website=eyefilm.nl}}</ref><ref name="Cinedans">{{cite web|url=http://cinedans.nl/2014/films/shorts-5-performative-film|title=Cinedans|website=cinedans.nl}}</ref> == References ==
{{reflist}}
== External links == *[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt9222558/ ''OCP'' on IMDb]

__NOTOC__ '''Opera America''', officially '''OPERA America''', is a service organization promoting the creation, presentation, and enjoyment of [[opera]] in the US.<ref>[http://www.operaamerica.org/applications/Membership/index.aspx Membership directory], Opera America</ref> Almost all professional opera companies and some semi-professional companies in the United States are members of the organization including such opera companies as the [[Metropolitan Opera]], [[San Francisco Opera]], [[Lyric Opera of Chicago]], and [[Dallas Opera]]. Opera America also includes international affiliated opera companies such as the [[Theatro Municipal (São Paulo)|Theatro Municipal de São Paulo]]. Opera America also hosts businesses, educational institutions, libraries, foundations, guilds, and opera artists such as singers and composers. It is also the home of New York Children's Opera Studio.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}} The organization was founded in 1970 and has been led by President and CEO Marc A. Scorca since 1990.
In April 2014, advisers from Opera America worked with [[San Diego Opera]] to develop a plan to prevent the company's closure.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2014/apr/18/san-diego-opera-closure-postponed/|title=S.D. Opera closure postponed to May 19; Newly reconstituted board will use time to raise money for 2015 season|last=Kragen|first=Pam|date=April 18, 2014|work=San Diego Union Tribune|accessdate=18 April 2014}}</ref>
Opera America's National Opera Center has two performance venues - Marc A. Scorca Hall and Plácido Domingo Hall. The National Opera Center has been the venue of performances by artists of companies such as Wolf Trap Opera. In 2016 and 2018, the Christman Opera Company premiered the operas ''Adriana McMannes'' and ''A Metamorphosis'' in Scorca Hall and Domingo Hall, respectively.[http://www.vocedimeche.reviews/2016/09/a-newborn-arrives.html][http://www.vocedimeche.reviews/2018/10/rachel-barg-sooyeon-kang-theodore.html][http://operawire.com/christman-opera-company-2018-review-adriana-mcmannes-a-metamorphosis/]
==See also== *[[Deutscher Bühnenverein]], equivalent national organization in Germany *[[Réunion des Opéras de France]], French national association *[[Opera Europa]], sister organisation covering Europe
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == *{{official|http://www.operaamerica.org/}}

{{Infobox film | name = Padmé | image = | caption = | Actor = Natalie Portman | producer = Robert Reeves Reeves
[[Kevin W. Walsh]]
[[Jason Ginsburg]] | writer = Kevin W. Walsh | starring = [[Lisa Vendette]]
Jason Ginsburg
Gerald Webb
Robin Johnstone
Robert Reeves
Kevin W. Walsh
Riley Rose Critchlow | music = [[Danny Kastner]] | cinematography = | editing = | studio = Evil Genius Entertainment,
ReevesReel | distributor = Atom.com | released = {{Film date|2008|07|01|Comic-Con International
Independent Film Festival}} | runtime = 4 minutes | country = | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Padmé''''' is a ''[[Star Wars]]'' [[fan film]] produced by [[Jason Ginsburg]], [[Robert Reeves (director)|Robert Reeves]], and [[Kevin W. Walsh]]. The short was written by Walsh and directed by Reeves. The film won the George Lucas Selects Award in the 2008 [[The Official Star Wars Fan Film Awards|Official Star Wars Fan Film Awards]], co-sponsored by [[Atom.com]] and [[Lucasfilm]],[http://io9.com/5031621/padm-wins-as-best-star-wars-fan-film-of-the-year io9 announcement] and aired on both [[Spike TV]][http://www.atom.com/funny_videos/sw_spike_promo_08/ Padme on Spike TV promo] and [[Comedy Central]][http://www.starwars.com/fans/media/20081002news.html Special "Atom TV" Episode Features the George Lucas 2008 Selects Winner, "Padmé"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081009080358/http://starwars.com/fans/media/20081002news.html |date=2008-10-09 }} shortly thereafter. Robert Reeves previously won Best Comedy in the 2005 Star Wars Fan Film Awards for ''Cheap Seats'', which he wrote, directed, and starred in.[[The Official Star Wars Fan Film Awards|Official Star Wars Fan Films Award Winners]] == Plot == The short is a virtual shot-for-shot remake of the [[teaser trailer]] for ''[[Juno (film)|Juno]]'', with the roles played by ''Star Wars'' characters. The film exploits the similarities between the characters of [[Padmé Amidala]] (from ''Star Wars'') and Juno MacGuff (from ''Juno''), two young women who find themselves unexpectedly pregnant. Both characters choose to give their children up for adoption and struggle with complex relationships with the children's fathers -- [[Anakin Skywalker]] filling the role of [[Paulie Bleeker]]. The mock trailer also showcases parodies of two songs featured in the Juno trailer: "[[Anyone Else But You]]" by '''[[Moldy Peaches|The Moldy Peaches]]''' is spoofed as "Part-Time Jedi / Full-Time Sith." And '''[[Mott the Hoople]]''''s "[[All the Young Dudes]]" is transformed into "All Jedi Dudes." == Cast == '''[[Padmé]]''', played by '''Lisa Vendette''', takes on the role of '''[[Juno MacGuff]]'''. '''[[Anakin Skywalker|Anakin]]''', '''[[Threepio]]''', and '''[[Yoda]]''', all played by '''Jason Ginsburg''', represent, respectively, '''[[Paulie Bleeker]]''', '''Leah''' (Juno's best friend), and the convenience store clerk played by '''[[Rainn Wilson]]'''. Ginsburg also appears in a non-speaking capacity as '''[[Palpatine]]'''. '''[[Mace Windu|Mace]]''', played by '''Gerald Webb''', acts as Juno's father, '''Mac MacGuff'''. '''Vanessa''', played by '''Robin Johnstone''', is unique in that she is the only character who comes entirely from the Juno film with no Star Wars counterpart. '''[[Bail Organa|Bail]]''', played by '''Robert Reeves''', parallels '''Mark Loring''', Vanessa's husband. Reeves also provided the voice of Yoda, in much the same way that [[James Earl Jones]] voiced [[Darth Vader]] in combination with the physical performance of [[David Prowse]]. '''[[Obi-Wan Kenobi|Obi-Wan]]''', played by '''Kevin Walsh''', represents Juno's stepmother, '''Bren MacGuff'''. '''Riley Rose Critchlow''' rounds out the cast in the capacity of a featured player. An '''[[R2-D2]]''' toy also appears briefly as the nurse from ''Juno'', projecting a hologram of Padmé's ultrasound. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.atom.com/funny_videos/sw_padme Padme on Atom] * [http://io9.com/5031621/padm-wins-as-best-star-wars-fan-film-of-the-year Announcement on sci-fi blog io9] * [http://www.generationstarwars.com/2008/08/padme-wins-george-lucas-selects-award.html George Lucas Selects Award press release] * [http://www.evilgents.com Evil Genius Entertainment, production company of Jason Ginsburg and Kevin W. Walsh] * {{IMDb title|1277725|Padmé}} {{Non-canon Star Wars}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Padme (film)}} [[Category:2008 films]] [[Category:2000s independent films]] [[Category:American independent films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Parody films]] [[Category:Fan films based on Star Wars]] [[Category:Pregnancy films]]
